For a Software house Building ApplicationJob Title: Senior Backend Developer (Java)Location: Cairo, Egypt (Remote work from other countries and other Governorates accepted)About the RoleWe are looking for a skilled and experienced Senior Backend Developer with expertise in Java to join our team. You will be responsible for designing, developing, and maintaining the backend services and APIs that power our mobile application.Responsibilities:Design and develop scalable and maintainable Java-based backend services and APIs.Implement robust and efficient database solutions.Ensure the performance, security, and reliability of our backend systems.Collaborate with frontend developers and other engineers to deliver a seamless user experience.Participate in code reviews and contribute to improving our development processes.Stay up-to-date with the latest Java technologies and best practices.Troubleshoot and debug backend issues efficiently.Qualifications:5+ years of professional experience in backend development.Strong proficiency in Java and Spring Boot (or similar frameworks).Experience with relational databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL) and NoSQL databases (e.g., MongoDB).Experience with cloud platforms (e.g., AWS, GCP, Azure).Strong understanding of RESTful APIs and microservices architecture.Experience with Agile development methodologies (e.g., Scrum, Kanban).Excellent problem-solving and debugging skills.Strong communication and collaboration skills.Bonus Points:Experience with containerization technologies (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes).Experience with message queues (e.g., Kafka, RabbitMQ).Experience with CI/CD pipelines for backend services.Experience with performance optimization and security best practices.To Apply:Please submit your resume and cover letter through a message on my LinkedIn profile. In your cover letter, please highlight your relevant experience and explain why you are a good fit for this role.Please mention Current and Expected salary. For a Software house Building ApplicationJob Title: Senior Backend Developer (Java)Location: Cairo, Egypt (Remote work from other countries and other Governorates accepted)About the RoleWe are looking for a skilled and experienced Senior Backend Developer with expertise in Java to join our team. You will be responsible for designing, developing, and maintaining the backend services and APIs that power our mobile application.Responsibilities:Design and develop scalable and maintainable Java-based backend services and APIs.Implement robust and efficient database solutions.Ensure the performance, security, and reliability of our backend systems.Collaborate with frontend developers and other engineers to deliver a seamless user experience.Participate in code reviews and contribute to improving our development processes.Stay up-to-date with the latest Java technologies and best practices.Troubleshoot and debug backend issues efficiently.Qualifications:5+ years of professional experience in backend development.Strong proficiency in Java and Spring Boot (or similar frameworks).Experience with relational databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL) and NoSQL databases (e.g., MongoDB).Experience with cloud platforms (e.g., AWS, GCP, Azure).Strong understanding of RESTful APIs and microservices architecture.Experience with Agile development methodologies (e.g., Scrum, Kanban).Excellent problem-solving and debugging skills.Strong communication and collaboration skills.Bonus Points:Experience with containerization technologies (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes).Experience with message queues (e.g., Kafka, RabbitMQ).Experience with CI/CD pipelines for backend services.Experience with performance optimization and security best practices.To Apply:Please submit your resume and cover letter through a message on my LinkedIn profile. In your cover letter, please highlight your relevant experience and explain why you are a good fit for this role.Please mention Current and Expected salary. ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

You will have the opportunity to work across the entire stack, from designing beautiful, responsive user interfaces to implementing business logic and managing databases. Your work will ensure a seamless experience for end users, optimizing performance, and making sure that both the front-end and back-end components integrate effectively.Responsibilities:â€¢	Full-Stack Development: Develop both the front-end and back-end of web applications using a variety of technologies, frameworks, and tools.â€¢	Front-End Development: Build responsive, user-friendly, and visually appealing interfaces using technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and modern front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Back-End Development: Design and implement server-side logic using technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#. Handle database operations, business logic, and API development.â€¢	Database Management: Design and implement relational and NoSQL databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB) to store and manage data efficiently.â€¢	API Integration: Build and integrate RESTful APIs and other services to facilitate communication between the front-end and back-end components.â€¢	CI/CD Setup: Set up and manage Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) pipelines to automate testing, integration, and deployment processes.â€¢	Collaboration: Work closely with product managers, designers, and other developers to define and implement application features and functionality.â€¢	Optimization: Ensure high-performance, scalable, and maintainable code by following best practices for both front-end and back-end development.Requirements:â€¢	Experience: 3+ years of experience in full-stack development with a strong focus on both front-end and back-end technologies.â€¢	Proficiency in front-end technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Strong knowledge of back-end technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#.â€¢	Experience with database management (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB).â€¢	Experience in developing RESTful APIs and integrating with third-party services.â€¢	Knowledge of version control systems, primarily Git.â€¢	Experience in setting up CI/CD pipelines using tools like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or Azure DevOps.â€¢	Familiarity with cloud platforms such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud for deploying applications.â€¢	Experience with Docker and containerization is a plus.â€¢	Good understanding of agile methodologies and working in an iterative development process.

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

We are hiring for hashtag#End-to-hashtag#End hashtag#Developer to work hashtag#remotely.You can hashtag#reach me at naveen.c@tachyontech.comRole: End-to-End DeveloperLocation: hashtag#Remote.Duration: Long-term.As an End-to-End Developer, you will be responsible for developing and maintaining both the front-end and back-end of web applications. You will have the opportunity to work across the entire stack, from designing beautiful, responsive user interfaces to implementing business logic and managing databases. Your work will ensure a seamless experience for end users, optimizing performance, and making sure that both the front-end and back-end components integrate effectively.Responsibilities:â€¢	Full-Stack Development: Develop both the front-end and back-end of web applications using a variety of technologies, frameworks, and tools.â€¢	Front-End Development: Build responsive, user-friendly, and visually appealing interfaces using technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and modern front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Back-End Development: Design and implement server-side logic using technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#. Handle database operations, business logic, and API development.â€¢	Database Management: Design and implement relational and NoSQL databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB) to store and manage data efficiently.â€¢	API Integration: Build and integrate RESTful APIs and other services to facilitate communication between the front-end and back-end components.â€¢	CI/CD Setup: Set up and manage Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) pipelines to automate testing, integration, and deployment processes.â€¢	Collaboration: Work closely with product managers, designers, and other developers to define and implement application features and functionality.â€¢	Optimization: Ensure high-performance, scalable, and maintainable code by following best practices for both front-end and back-end development.Requirements:â€¢	Experience: 3+ years of experience in full-stack development with a strong focus on both front-end and back-end technologies.â€¢	Proficiency in front-end technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Strong knowledge of back-end technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#.â€¢	Experience with database management (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB).â€¢	Experience in developing RESTful APIs and integrating with third-party services.â€¢	Knowledge of version control systems, primarily Git.â€¢	Experience in setting up CI/CD pipelines using tools like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or Azure DevOps.â€¢	Familiarity with cloud platforms such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud for deploying applications.â€¢	Experience with Docker and containerization is a plus.â€¢	Good understanding of agile methodologies and working in an iterative development process.

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

We are hiring for hashtag#End-to-hashtag#End hashtag#Developer to work hashtag#remotely.You can hashtag#reach me at naveen.c@tachyontech.comRole: End-to-End DeveloperLocation: hashtag#Remote.Duration: Long-term.As an End-to-End Developer, you will be responsible for developing and maintaining both the front-end and back-end of web applications. You will have the opportunity to work across the entire stack, from designing beautiful, responsive user interfaces to implementing business logic and managing databases. Your work will ensure a seamless experience for end users, optimizing performance, and making sure that both the front-end and back-end components integrate effectively.Responsibilities:â€¢	Full-Stack Development: Develop both the front-end and back-end of web applications using a variety of technologies, frameworks, and tools.â€¢	Front-End Development: Build responsive, user-friendly, and visually appealing interfaces using technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and modern front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Back-End Development: Design and implement server-side logic using technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#. Handle database operations, business logic, and API development.â€¢	Database Management: Design and implement relational and NoSQL databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB) to store and manage data efficiently.â€¢	API Integration: Build and integrate RESTful APIs and other services to facilitate communication between the front-end and back-end components.â€¢	CI/CD Setup: Set up and manage Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) pipelines to automate testing, integration, and deployment processes.â€¢	Collaboration: Work closely with product managers, designers, and other developers to define and implement application features and functionality.â€¢	Optimization: Ensure high-performance, scalable, and maintainable code by following best practices for both front-end and back-end development.Requirements:â€¢	Experience: 3+ years of experience in full-stack development with a strong focus on both front-end and back-end technologies.â€¢	Proficiency in front-end technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Strong knowledge of back-end technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#.â€¢	Experience with database management (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB).â€¢	Experience in developing RESTful APIs and integrating with third-party services.â€¢	Knowledge of version control systems, primarily Git.â€¢	Experience in setting up CI/CD pipelines using tools like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or Azure DevOps.â€¢	Familiarity with cloud platforms such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud for deploying applications.â€¢	Experience with Docker and containerization is a plus.â€¢	Good understanding of agile methodologies and working in an iterative development process.

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

We are hiring for hashtag#End-to-hashtag#End hashtag#Developer to work hashtag#remotely.You can hashtag#reach me at naveen.c@tachyontech.comRole: End-to-End DeveloperLocation: hashtag#Remote.Duration: Long-term.As an End-to-End Developer, you will be responsible for developing and maintaining both the front-end and back-end of web applications. You will have the opportunity to work across the entire stack, from designing beautiful, responsive user interfaces to implementing business logic and managing databases. Your work will ensure a seamless experience for end users, optimizing performance, and making sure that both the front-end and back-end components integrate effectively.Responsibilities:â€¢	Full-Stack Development: Develop both the front-end and back-end of web applications using a variety of technologies, frameworks, and tools.â€¢	Front-End Development: Build responsive, user-friendly, and visually appealing interfaces using technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and modern front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Back-End Development: Design and implement server-side logic using technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#. ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

For a Software house Building ApplicationJob Title: Senior Backend Developer (Java)Location: Cairo, Egypt (Remote work from other countries and other Governorates accepted)About the RoleWe are looking for a skilled and experienced Senior Backend Developer with expertise in Java to join our team. ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

We are hiring for hashtag#End-to-hashtag#End hashtag#Developer to work hashtag#remotely.You can hashtag#reach me at naveen.c@tachyontech.comRole: End-to-End DeveloperLocation: hashtag#Remote.Duration: Long-term.As an End-to-End Developer, you will be responsible for developing and maintaining both the front-end and back-end of web applications. You will have the opportunity to work across the entire stack, from designing beautiful, responsive user interfaces to implementing business logic and managing databases. Your work will ensure a seamless experience for end users, optimizing performance, and making sure that both the front-end and back-end components integrate effectively.Responsibilities:â€¢	Full-Stack Development: Develop both the front-end and back-end of web applications using a variety of technologies, frameworks, and tools.â€¢	Front-End Development: Build responsive, user-friendly, and visually appealing interfaces using technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and modern front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Back-End Development: Design and implement server-side logic using technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#. Handle database operations, business logic, and API development.â€¢	Database Management: Design and implement relational and NoSQL databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB) to store and manage data efficiently.â€¢	API Integration: Build and integrate RESTful APIs and other services to facilitate communication between the front-end and back-end components.â€¢	CI/CD Setup: Set up and manage Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) pipelines to automate testing, integration, and deployment processes.â€¢	Collaboration: Work closely with product managers, designers, and other developers to define and implement application features and functionality.â€¢	Optimization: Ensure high-performance, scalable, and maintainable code by following best practices for both front-end and back-end development.Requirements:â€¢	Experience: 3+ years of experience in full-stack development with a strong focus on both front-end and back-end technologies.â€¢	Proficiency in front-end technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Strong knowledge of back-end technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#.â€¢	Experience with database management (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB).â€¢	Experience in developing RESTful APIs and integrating with third-party services.â€¢	Knowledge of version control systems, primarily Git.â€¢	Experience in setting up CI/CD pipelines using tools like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or Azure DevOps.â€¢	Familiarity with cloud platforms such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud for deploying applications.â€¢	Experience with Docker and containerization is a plus.â€¢	Good understanding of agile methodologies and working in an iterative development process.

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

Here are three reasons why Montilla should be at the top of your list. Firstly, Montilla offers an idyllic work-life balance. Nestled in the heart of Andalusia, this picturesque town combines the tranquility of countryside living with all the necessary amenities for a productive workday. You can enjoy breathtaking vineyard views and serene landscapes, providing the perfect backdrop for creative and focused work sessions. Secondly, Montilla is home to nomad-friendly hotels, specifically designed for remote professionals. ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Drop your thoughts in the comments!ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’¬hashtag#Java hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#Applets hashtag#Servlets hashtag#Backend hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment ğŸš€

Here are three reasons why Montilla should be at the top of your list. Firstly, Montilla offers an idyllic work-life balance. ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor

We are hiring for hashtag#End-to-hashtag#End hashtag#Developer to work hashtag#remotely.You can hashtag#reach me at naveen.c@tachyontech.comRole: End-to-End DeveloperLocation: hashtag#Remote.Duration: Long-term.As an End-to-End Developer, you will be responsible for developing and maintaining both the front-end and back-end of web applications. You will have the opportunity to work across the entire stack, from designing beautiful, responsive user interfaces to implementing business logic and managing databases. Your work will ensure a seamless experience for end users, optimizing performance, and making sure that both the front-end and back-end components integrate effectively.Responsibilities:â€¢	Full-Stack Development: Develop both the front-end and back-end of web applications using a variety of technologies, frameworks, and tools.â€¢	Front-End Development: Build responsive, user-friendly, and visually appealing interfaces using technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and modern front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Back-End Development: Design and implement server-side logic using technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#. Handle database operations, business logic, and API development.â€¢	Database Management: Design and implement relational and NoSQL databases (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB) to store and manage data efficiently.â€¢	API Integration: Build and integrate RESTful APIs and other services to facilitate communication between the front-end and back-end components.â€¢	CI/CD Setup: Set up and manage Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) pipelines to automate testing, integration, and deployment processes.â€¢	Collaboration: Work closely with product managers, designers, and other developers to define and implement application features and functionality.â€¢	Optimization: Ensure high-performance, scalable, and maintainable code by following best practices for both front-end and back-end development.Requirements:â€¢	Experience: 3+ years of experience in full-stack development with a strong focus on both front-end and back-end technologies.â€¢	Proficiency in front-end technologies like HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and front-end frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js.â€¢	Strong knowledge of back-end technologies such as Node.js, Java, Python, or C#.â€¢	Experience with database management (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB).â€¢	Experience in developing RESTful APIs and integrating with third-party services.â€¢	Knowledge of version control systems, primarily Git.â€¢	Experience in setting up CI/CD pipelines using tools like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or Azure DevOps.â€¢	Familiarity with cloud platforms such as AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud for deploying applications.â€¢	Experience with Docker and containerization is a plus.â€¢	Good understanding of agile methodologies and working in an iterative development process.

ğŸš€ Java Applets vs. Java Servlets â€“ Explained with Real-Life Examples! â˜•ğŸ’»If youâ€™ve ever wondered what Applets and Servlets are in Java, this post will clear everything up for you! Let's break it down with real-world examples so that even someone new to Java can understand.ğŸ–¥ï¸ What is a Java Applet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Applet is a small Java program that runs inside a web browser. It is used to create dynamic and interactive web applications.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Think of a mini-game on a website (like an old Flash game). When you open the webpage, the game loads and runs inside the browser.ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Applets:âœ… Runs in a web browser (requires a Java plugin).âœ… Uses java.applet package.âœ… Requires an HTML page to run.âœ… Mostly deprecated now due to security issues and modern web technologies replacing it.ğŸŒ What is a Java Servlet?ğŸ‘‰ Definition: A Java Servlet is a server-side program that handles client requests (like form submissions) and generates dynamic web content.ğŸ‘‰ Real-Life Example: Imagine you order food online ğŸ”ğŸ“¦. When you click â€œOrder Now,â€ the request goes to the restaurantâ€™s system (server), processes your request, and sends a confirmation. A Servlet works like that restaurantâ€™s backend systemâ€”handling requests and sending responses!ğŸ“Œ Key Points about Servlets:âœ… Runs on a server (not a browser).âœ… Uses javax.servlet package.âœ… Handles HTTP requests (GET, POST).âœ… Forms the backbone of Java-based web applications like online banking, e-commerce, and social media platforms.ğŸ’¡ Final ThoughtğŸ“Œ Applets were great for interactive web content but are no longer used due to security risks and better alternatives (JavaScript, React, etc.).ğŸ“Œ Servlets, on the other hand, are still a core part of Java web development and power many websites today!Hope this helped! Have you ever worked with Servlets or Applets? Here are three reasons why Montilla should be at the top of your list. Firstly, Montilla offers an idyllic work-life balance. Nestled in the heart of Andalusia, this picturesque town combines the tranquility of countryside living with all the necessary amenities for a productive workday. You can enjoy breathtaking vineyard views and serene landscapes, providing the perfect backdrop for creative and focused work sessions. Secondly, Montilla is home to nomad-friendly hotels, specifically designed for remote professionals. Many accommodations here are equipped with desks, ergonomic chairs, and high-speed internet, ensuring a seamless transition between work obligations and leisure activities. You'll find everything you need to maintain productivity without sacrificing comfort. Lastly, Montilla boasts a vibrant cultural scene and a welcoming community. With its rich history, you can explore wineries, traditional cuisine, and local festivals during your downtime. The friendly locals make it easy to connect and immerse yourself in authentic Spanish culture, providing a rewarding experience both professionally and personally. ğŸš¨ Say No to Free Take-Home Assessments! ğŸš¨In tech, we talk a lot about valuing engineers' time, yet unpaid take-home assessments remain a standard part of hiring. These tasks can take hoursâ€”sometimes even daysâ€”of research, coding, testing, and documentation.âŒ For companies, itâ€™s free labor.â³ For candidates, itâ€™s an investment with no guarantee of return.Many of us are already juggling full-time jobs, personal responsibilities, and (for some) even job hunting while unemployed. Expecting engineers to complete unpaid work as part of the hiring process undervalues their expertise.âœ… Some companies do it rightâ€”offering compensation for take-home projects or alternatives like live technical discussions or pair programming. Others treat it as an unpaid trial, often leading nowhere.ğŸ’° My rate on Upwork is $30 per hour, and if a company expects me to spend hours on a take-home project, I expect to be compensated accordingly.After 8 years in this field, I am no longer willing to do free work. My skills, experience, and track record prove my expertiseâ€”no take-home test can showcase that better than my real-world results.ğŸ“¢ Itâ€™s time for a shift. If a company requires a significant take-home project, it should be paid.#ğŸš€ hashtag#SayNoToFreeWork hashtag#TechHiring hashtag#FairPay hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#hiring hashtag#cv hashtag#coding hashtag#work hashtag#job hashtag#trend hashtag#fyp hashtag#top hashtag#reach hashtag#PayForWork hashtag#Engineering hashtag#NoFreeLabor
